Loggers#

Module contents#

Submodules#

Logger Interface#

class swarmsim.Loggers.base_logger.BaseLogger(populations, environment, config_path)[source]#

Bases: Logger

A class that implements a logger.

Parameters:

  • populations (list of instances of clas populations.)

  • environment (Instance of class environment.)

  • config_path (str (Path of the configuration file).)

Variables:

  • config (-)

  • activate (-)

  • date (-)

  • log_freq (-)

  • save_freq (-)

  • log_path (-)

  • comment_enable (-)

  • populations (-)

  • environment (-)

  • name (-)

  • log_name_csv (-)

  • log_name_txt (-)

  • log_name_npz (-)

  • start (-)

  • end (-)

  • step_count (-)

  • done (-)

  • current_info (-)

Configuration file requirements

  • activate: bool True to have logger, False otherwise

  • log_freq: int Print every log_freq steps information (0: never print)

  • save_freq: int Save every save_freq steps information (0: never save)

  • comment_enable: bool If true, add initial and final comments to the logger about the experiment

  • log_path: str Path where logger output should be saved

  • log_name: str String appended to date in the name of the file

Notes

If active, outputs two files: one .csv computer-readable and one .txt human-readable named DATEname.csv and DATEname.txt, respectively. Moreover, save_data stores a .npz of the data given in input.

reset()[source]#

Reset logger at the beginning of the simulation. Verifies if active, reset step counter and start time counter

Returns:

activate (bool flag to check whether the logger is active)

Return type:

bool

log(data=None)[source]#

A function that defines the information to log.

Parameters:

data (dict composed of {name_variabile: value} to log)

Returns:

done (bool flag to truncate a simulation early. Default value=False.)

Notes

In the configuration file (a yaml file) there should be a namespace with the name of the log you are creating. By default, it does not truncate episode early. See add_data from Utils/logger_utils.py to quickly add variables to log.

close(data=None)[source]#

Function to store final step information, end-of-the-experiment information and close logger

Parameters:

data (dict composed of {name_variabile: value} to log)

Returns:

activate (bool flag to check whether the logger is active)

Return type:

bool

log_external_data(data, print_flag=False, txt_flag=False, csv_flag=False, npz_flag=True, mat_flag=True)[source]#
log_internal_data(print_flag=True, txt_flag=True, csv_flag=True, npz_flag=False, mat_flag=False)[source]#

data (dict (composed of {name_variabile: value} to log))

Returns:

done (bool (flag to truncate a simulation early). Default value=False.)

Return type:

bool

Notes

In the configuration file (a yaml file) there should be a namespace with the name of the log you are creating. By default, it does not truncate episode early.

Configuration file requirements

  • activate: bool True to have logger, False otherwise

  • log_freq: int Print every log_freq steps information (0: never print)

  • save_freq: int Save every save_freq steps information (0: never save)

  • comment_enable: bool If true, add initial and final comments to the logger about the experiment

  • log_path: str Path where logger output should be saved

  • log_name: str String appended to date in the name of the file

Notes

If active, outputs two files: one .csv computer-readable and one .txt human-readable named DATEname.csv and DATEname.txt, respectively. Moreover, save_data stores a .npz of the data given in input.
